(philosophy) Scientific knowledge; a principled system of understanding; sometimes contrasted with empiricism.
(specifically Ancient Greek philosophy) know-how; compare techne.

(specifically Foucaultian philosophy) The fundamental body of ideas and collective presuppositions that defines the nature and sets the bounds of what is accepted as true knowledge in a given epistemic epoch.
(philosophy) Of or relating to cognition or knowledge, its scope, or how it is acquired.
(by extension, linguistics) Of or relating to how cognition or knowledge is expressed in language.
(philosophy) Of or relating to epistemology ("the branch of philosophy dealing with the study of knowledge"); epistemologic or epistemological.
In an epistemic way, as:
In a way that pertains to knowledge and cognition.
(usually, more specifically) In a way that pertains to metaknowledge and epistemology (awareness of the source, truth, and epistemologic grounding of knowledge).
Of or pertaining to epistemology or theory of knowledge, as a field of study.

In a manner that pertains to epistemology.
(loosely) In a manner that pertains to knowledge or cognition.
A person, especially a philosopher, who studies theory of knowledge.

(uncountable) The branch of philosophy dealing with the study of knowledge; the theory of knowledge, asking such questions as "What is knowledge?", "How is knowledge acquired?", "What do people know?", "How do we know what we know?", "How do we know it is true?", and so on.
examples: Some thinkers take the view that, beginning with the work of Descartes, epistemology began to replace metaphysics as the most important area of philosophy.

senses.sense: (countable) A particular instance, version, or school thereof; a particular theory of knowledge.
examples: In his epistemology, Plato maintains that our knowledge of universal concepts is a kind of recollection.

senses.sense: An excessive love of, or striving for, knowledge.

(biology) A microorganism (such as a yeast-type fungus or a protozoon) that grows on the surface of an animal host, as:
(usually) In a nonparasitic way, using an animal's skin as a microhabitat.
(less commonly) In a parasitic way, as an external parasite.
(epidemiology) An occurrence of a disease or disorder in a population of non-human animals at a frequency higher than that expected in a given time period. Compare epidemic.
examples: At the same time as an epidemic of the flu broke out among the people, an epizootic of the swine flu broke out among their pigs.

senses.sense: A particular epizootic disease.
(dialectal, humorous, often in the plural) A disease or ailment (of humans).
examples: Johnny's not doing so well today, I think he caught the epizootic.

senses.sense: (epidemiology) Like or having to do with an epizootic: epidemic among animals.
examples: Epizootic plague occurred in the mice following introduction of rats from Europe.

senses.sense: (geology, rare) Containing fossils.
Relating to epizoa; epizoic.
In the manner of an epizootic; in a way that affects a particular species or range of species.
Regarding epizootics; in the context of the study of epizootics.

Relating to epizootiology.
In an epizootiological manner

An epizootic disease or outbreak.
A particular period of history, or of a person's life, especially one considered noteworthy or remarkable.
A notable event which marks the beginning of such a period.
(chronology, astronomy, computing) A specific instant in time, chosen as the point of reference or zero value of a system that involves identifying instants of time.
(geology) A geochronologic unit of hundreds of thousands to millions of years; a subdivision of a period, and subdivided into ages (or sometimes subepochs).
(ML) One complete presentation of the training data set to an iterative machine learning algorithm.
examples: The neural network was trained over 500 epochs.

senses.sense: (sciences, transitive) To divide (data) into segments by time period.

Of or pertaining to an epoch.

A real or fictitious person or thing whose name has given rise to the name of a particular item.
examples: Romulus is the eponym of Rome.

senses.sense: A word formed from a real or fictive person’s name.
examples: Rome is an eponym of Romulus.

senses.sense: (loosely, nonstandard, by extension) A word formed from a real or fictive place or thing.

Of, relating to, or being the person or entity after which someone or something is named; serving as an eponym.
examples: Prince Hamlet is the eponymous protagonist of the Shakespearian tragedy Hamlet.
Robinson Crusoe is the eponymous hero of the book.
The language Limburgish is named after the eponymous provinces in Belgium and the Netherlands.

senses.sense: Of a thing: named after a person or entity.
examples: The American singer-songwriter Madonna released her eponymous album in 1983.
